The Last of Us 2 represents how games sh: So to be quite frank\, I don’t understand what everyone’s deal with this game is. While yes\, the developers killed off Joel\, you need to understand not only why the developers made that choice\, but why Abby as a character was so motivated to do so.While we can sympathize with him and try to minimize his actions\, what Joel did to the Fireflies was an objectively horrible act that prevented the world from being saved for his own selfish desire to have a daughter figure back. Even Joel knows this\, considering he lied to Ellie for so long about it. While I didn’t want Joel to die\, that’s why I personally felt motivated to engage in Ellie’s borderline suicidal pursuit for revenge. It was not the period of events we wanted\, but it was one vital to the progression of Ellie’s character.I’ve heard complaints of how characters act “out of character” in this game\, which is not true at all. The world of TLOU is not a world for pure protagonists. Taking Ellie as the main character being targeted by this critique\, she is an incredibly traumatized young woman living in a world of constant fear and danger. It’s entirely unrealistic to expect her to be anything less than majorly flawed.In Abby’s story\, I found the humanization of those I had previously hated to be a very unique and cognitively challenging hurdle to get over. I killed these people earlier as Ellie\, and now they appear as more than targets. They’re allies and friends. Abby’s story pulls more from the original game than Ellie’s story does. It’s a bunch of new characters rediscovering a feeling of purity and innocence only for that to be squashed by the events of the world around them. It’s an incredibly sad and effective tale that causes even more distress when I have to pin the two against each other.For people criticizing the writing of the dialogue\, all I’m going to ask is what did you get out of the first game that the dialogue of this one was so ‘bad’?I saw one comment about the game getting ‘political’. What? What’s political about the game? The fact that Ellie’s gay?
